review_title: I loved working for UHG and would return with zero hesitation.
job_title: Senior Director Operations in Minnetonka, MN
pros: The pace and complexity of the industry and the organization and the constant change is engaging and energizing and provides for boundless opportunity if you are a driven, proactive, innovative thinker. Environment is ripe for making your mark and being a part of transformational change on many fronts. Exceptionally bright leadership that knows the industry and has driven growth, performance and changes that is a story largely untold--clouded by the media sensationalism around health care. UHG Is much more than a managed care organization, long ago intentionally positioned on a diversified platform for market volatility stabilization and to leverage its scale and expertise to lead change in many ways that get little attention despite the innovation and impact. The leaders of this company (led by Steve Hemsley) had insight decades back that was then and is now, truly sector changing. Their story is one to pause and spend time examining. It might not be a front runner in B school business cases because it's doesn't have that sector appeal that, say, retail does. But it should be. If you want to grow and be challenged ahead of your time and experience things many of your peers have not and may not--this is the place. Can be tough and intense--but because you are pushed to perform and be accountable. Big enough that the lazy can hide and grumble and complain wallowing in pity---for a while. They are always unearthed eventually. No org is perfect including United--some criticisms are legit I'm sure, but many--would simply say--knew the types and overall--their self election to move on to a more blasé environment was probably a good move. Outstanding professional organization to flourish in.
cons: Phrase is: it depends. It's a huge place. If there is a con, it could be simply the person or team you work for--nothing more, nothing less. And if you perform, simply align with an advocate that can be a fan and have your back and move to another area. They encourage it and the choices are endless. IF---you deliver. It's action oriented and fast paced. Do what you say. Ask and challenged. Be thorough but not paralyzed. Well thought decisions are respected even if they don't work out as planned--it's the inattentive and disengaged "don't get it factor" types that get caught in the crossfire of intolerance for mediocrity. That battle can be harsh from what I saw. Just in my opinion however.

job_title: Customer Service Representative II in Tampa, FL
pros: Having employment opposed to not being unemployed. Some overtime opportunities, hour lunches. If you're a smoker you'll fit right in! The majority of the employees are smokers, so the rules on where you can smoke isn't harshly enforced.
cons: Communication between upper level management and staff could've been better. Rules would be placed without notifying the staff, yet you'd be held accountable. Pay for performance, management switching you to different departments and schedules, gossip between employees, not being allowed to have a basic conversation with your neighbors, even when all work is done. Very tense work environment, management uses favoritism, guidelines are enforced at management discretion opposed to the same rules applying to everyone.

review_title: Been around the block, & there is nothing better than this
pros:
Very flexible schedule, self scheduling when you want to work. Generous salary & PTO. 6-8pt per day & EVERYTHING is virtual. No office to go to and no actual treatment as all you are doing is a physical assessment & patient education. At the end of every yr I have to start taking vacation days because I don't end up using all of them. I just love going to work. Most of us work 4 day work weeks but it's up to you. As long as you do 40hrs per wk they don't care how you do it. The company sends us out to a yearly summit somewhere which is amazing. Management is available if needed but not overwhelming. Benefits package is great. 
Coming from primary care & LTC where I was way overwhelmed, overworked and unappreciated, this was a welcome change and I am having a ball. The work/life balance is the best.
cons:
You have to be able to be self reliant and independent. Which to me isn't a con but it can be a little intimidating to some. However, there is zero treatment, just assessments so it limits what you can do for the patient other than providing instruction and contacting pcp for acute situations. 
Another con is that you are driving everywhere, so if you don't like driving-this is not for you. 
Also, you are walking into patient's homes which can at times not be pleasant. If you are squeamish, it can be a problem. 
Patients are members to administration and they survey them after we leave, members feedback is very important so if they didn't like you for whatever reason you will hear of it. Generally it's not a big problem

job_title: Health Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: If you enjoy talking to people this is a good job.  There is a satisfaction when you're able to help a member understand how and why their claims were processed like they were.  Also if you like to do volunteer work or fund raisers United is very involved in these things.
cons: United gives you a chance to make extra money if you meet their stats.  However, it's very difficult to meet them because they are set so high.  United doesn't really care about them employees or the members, it's all about meeting the numbers. This company also does not offer their employees good health insurance.  Most of the members have better benefits.

pros: Offered the option to work at home, great stock options, great 401k matching, decent amount of PTO time.
cons: There is not a lot of opportunity to advance. They hire more outside than in. The raises are terrible even when your yearly reviews are excellent. It's difficult to use your pto. Health benefits are okay at best. They focus on what computer systems say that you are doing and so many micromanagement tools that it's hard to stay motivated. Bonuses are always weak

pros:
-If you are hardworking and self driven, there is forward movement in your career. 
-Optum is part of United Health Group so there are many different positions you can move to
-Many opportunities for telecommuting. I work full time remote and the organization is structured to support this alternative work style
-If you look, there are opportunities for career growth
-Very metric driven organization since this specific sector develops products for customers. If you meet your metrics, the annual bonuses are good. Past bonuses were $4700, $7800 with the last one being $9,000. 
-Fast paced and you won't be bored if you are in the right position
-In the product development side, if you really want to contribute and make change; the squeaky wheel works. It's rewarding to be part of improving products that customers use. 
-401K is decent; match is 3-5% and managed by Fidelity
-Opportunities to work with charities and contribute to your community  
-I have worked here for almost 6 years and every year; I have gotten 5% salary raises, annual bonuses ranging from 4k - 9k and have even gotten small awards throughout the year. This helps offset the smaller salary I initially started with. Since this was telecommute; I factored into the savings of commuting which was fine for me.
cons:
-For an insurance company; the benefits and health insurance package are shameful ! Compared to all other previous employers such as Kaiser; the plans they offer here are horrible. They are high deductible plans with even worse prescription coverage. They offer an HSA which they match but that's only because their plans are horrible to start with. Luckily for myself, I am relatively healthy. If I had a chronic condition or needed maintenance meds; I'd be broke. It is clear that the organization knows they need to keep premiums cheaper for non UHG employees and they stick us with the worst Insurance plans because employees don't have a choice. My husband's employer actually offers United Health insurance at a much better premium than what I as an employee is eligible for. That's shameful.  
-One of the pros I mentioned was Optum is part of UHG which is a huge org. It is also a con in some ways because each department runs things differently. There is no cohesion or leveraging of the work. Some managers are very territorial of their department and are reluctant to work together. 
-I understand every position needs metrics in order to measure work. But this department measures the wrong things. The metrics they use are not always motivating to all its employees
-Product development is fast paced and ever changing; which may not suit every person. Some employees want to do their minimum  and as much as I felt rewarded (with my annual bonus and positive reviews), it felt unfair when others were just mediocre
-They depend heavily on offshore work with teams in India and the Philippines. This is a challenge. I think offshore work is appropriate in some type of work for example data entry. Data is Data right? The problems I have seen is when they trust offshore employees to use their reasoning and judgement to complete work that they don't have experience doing. When I have personally witnessed sub par work being done by an offshore team; I have gotten the impression it is not in my scope and to mind my business. 
-You have to come in at a decent salary. Once you get in; you won't be able to negotiate for a higher salary and the only way to make a more significant salary is to switch jobs. I have seen employees come into the same position with varied salaries from 60,000 to 80,000 and this is for the same pay grade and everyone doing the same work.

review_title: Great Place to Work but with Major Drawbacks
job_title: Project Manager in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
- As mentioned in the title, the culture is very good at Optum (UnitedHealth Group) and it is a great place to work. The majority of people that I met were helpful and friendly as well as hardworking.

- The Optum Technology Development Program (TDP) is a nice program for college graduates and individuals looking to get their hands on the various departments and technologies within IT at Optum

- WFH is available depending on your department. If your department approves of it, then you will have a good work-life balance

- Offices are located in nice towns and the workspaces + equipment are comfortable. However, there was a major push to open-space sitting so despite the great looks of it, many were not fond of it

- Good benefits such as discounted health insurance and employee discounts on many retailers and brands

- Excellent PTO (approximately 23 days depending on paygrade and increases every 5 years)

- Many opportunities to grow in your career, learn new skills and achieve certifications. Most of the trainings that were provided were top-notch.
cons:
- Poor leadership and management. Senior leaders are too busy looking at financials while directors and managers are too busy in their own work to deal with their direct reports

- While the Technology Development Program (TDP) is a nice start for college graduates and new employees, it has some major flaws. As stated above, directors and managers are too busy in their own work to deal with "TDPers" and guide them in their careers. Also, Optum doesn't offer enough to TDPers to keep them at Optum because of what is out there in the market at other firms. It went from a program with a nice start and good intentions to a numbers game where it was just about flooding the company with "tech-savvy millennials" leading to many hungry college graduates sitting around with nothing to do, a lack of motivation, and no guidance.

- Constant layoffs and changes in organizational structure. When I joined Optum, there had been massive company wide layoffs the year before and it was stable for about 2 years and then they had a year of massive hiring. Then after the 3rd year there were massive layoffs about every month. I was shocked that many senior leaders who had been in the company for 30+ years also got laid off (some of them were pioneers of amazing work at Optum/United). These layoffs caused alarm bells to ring throughout the company and put every employee on edge about their job.

- Poor pay structure and employee review system. I guess the benefits like PTO and discounted health insurance make up for the pay structure somewhat however the market has much more to offer now that the company is not as stable as it used to be (in terms of job security). The employee review system is also highly flawed as it makes it very difficult for anyone to move up in paygrade due to unrealistic expectations from senior leadership and lack of guidance from management.

- Projects and work were never stable. There would either be too much work for one person to handle or no work at all.

- Old technologies and too many processes. Though this was slowly changing, Optum is still very far behind the competition and other tech firms out there

- WFH allowance varied by department but it was mainly seen with a negative stigma by senior leadership.

review_title: everything you'd fear about working for an insurance company
pros: So many great people. There are opportunities to make changes if you're a self-starter. There are pockets of excellence all over. There are a few really good executives doing the right thing.
cons: Executive leadership operates like game of thrones. Lots of dysfunctional behavior. Bad practice of antiquated management techniques. Silo behavior is the norm. Many malevolent people are protected and put into positions of senior leadership. Competency has little bearing in senior leadership assignments. The financial "discipline" squeezes water from pennies. So while you are hearing that the company is fiscally doing great, you can expect to not even get a cost of living raise. The business is mostly run by bureaucrats who reward compliance over performance.  So many executives sit in their private offices and summon audiences to them without understanding how things work 2 or 3 levels down. You may need to apply for a role above your pay grade if you want a promotion; it's actually much easier than getting a promotion (thanks again to the finance bureaucrats). Bonuses come only once per year. They can be quite generous, but only really apply to what was in your manager's most recent memory of you, and they are highly discretionary in nature. As a matter of policy, remote work is discouraged. Some good leaders disregard that policy. We aren't empowered to hire or retain bright people, but we're so big that we've got some anyway. I expect we could cut half of our workforce, many executives and non value-add roles, and be a remarkably more successful company.

review_title: Fine If You're a Manager, Drone for the Workers
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
-Good salary, good compensation (401K and health plan in particular)
-Nice cafeteria with healthy food
-Beautiful surrounding area with a good walking path
-It's very easy to hide. You can easily get away with doing nothing for a good long time. I spent, like three months, doing no work, turning nothing in. And no one noticed. Of course, that could be a con if you like making connections--it means no one's paying attention to you.
-Good work-from-home policy. No one bats an eye as long as you put it on the calendar. I get about 10 notifications per day from people working from home. I've never been chastized for it, or seen a restriction need to be regulated.
cons:
What you get out of working there depends on what kind of person you are. I wish I could be more negative, but really, UHG is so big everyone's going to have a different experience. But here's mine.  

From what I saw, they put more attention on managers and decisions-makers than those who do the grunt work. And there are managers everywhere (it's managers all the way down). Your boss will spend more time looking up at his or her manager, making sure they approve, than down at their employees making sure they have what they need. They don't have to deal with IT problems when it takes days just to merge your two lines of code into master because of something eight levels removed. 

My team was way too big for an Agile methodology. In-office developers alone, there were 24 of us. You can't have a stand-up meeting with that many people. And that's not counting QAs or BAs. The software is EXTRAORDINARILY complex and tightly coupled. The main branch often breaks because it's so tightly coupled so someone can easily commit something that breaks it for everyone. They adhere so tightly to Agile Scrum, but don't say "no" to the hard decisions (e.g. regularly booking way over capacity, two week iterations that don't improve the product, but make it so those managers know what to expect so they can tell their managers). Nothing is spelled out, there's operational knowledge in scattered people's brains everywhere.

Creativity is not valued. By the time you get a spec to implement (which, good luck to know where your marching orders come from each day) it's been so finely tuned it's basically in pseudocode at that point. Their policies are dictated by out-of-touch managers six levels up. For example, no one has a personal space. You're expected to clear it off every end-of-day. This is so you can take your laptop anywhere to converse with others. Except A) most people need something of theirs to keep at their desk, like a keyboard rest or special chair or coffee mug B) you can't get to know anyone if they always sit in a different place. You only know them by names, not faces or location. How are you supposed to get to know anyone if you can't find them? So you end up using e-mail or IM for everything, even if they're right next to you.

They say they care about employees, but make no effort to make personal connections to them. I've been confronted with certain actions that were based entirely on hearsay evidence and the "no one else seems to have a problem figuring this out" deal. I've literally never had a conversation with my team leader (and I've had three in the 2 years I've been there. Four if you count having "no manager" for three or four months). And therefore I have no interest in pleasing that person.

Everything is by e-mail. Policy changes, organization changes, team get-togethers, all by e-mail. A team lunch can have 23 people. How are you supposed to get to know anyone in that capacity? Every year they post a workplace survey, and bug everybody to complete it, but I've never seen anyone change based on it. I was on the survey team one year and I saw point after point ignored. They even said they ignore the comments.

Other:
-Open-plan office makes you feel anxious and watched. I always feel like my job is in peril. Lighting comes from skylights or dim flourescents, like a warehouse.
-The free coffee is bad. I mean, it makes me sick. Makes me feel like there's a brick in my stomach. But you can always buy from their company coffee shop.
-Lots of contractors and consultants. You never know who's who or when they're going to disappear. Goodbye subject matter experts.
-Their technology policies are oppressive and dictatorial. They have an oppressive proxy you can't get around (meaning no YouTube, no Instagram, no Pinterest). You can't install any unauthorized software--they have a special program that monitors for it and an "appStore" that does all the installations from approved applications automagically. So if you like OpenOffice better than Word, you're out of luck. You're not allowed to use Chrome, you have to use IE or an old version of Firefox.
-No advancement whatsoever. I don't know how you're supposed to get noticed in this job, unless you're just charismatic.

review_title: You are more of a customer service person than a helpdesk analyst.
job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Saint Louis Park, MN
pros:
- This is a enterprise helpdesk on steroids. The helpdesk supports 74000+ end users with 4500 different software applications. UHG through all sorts of mergers and acquisitions likely has every platform known to man - Unisys and IBM mainframes, every flavor of Unix, Windows servers, Cisco VoIP phones, Cisco VPN, etc. Last I heard the company processes 1 billion claims/year. This company probably has more data bandwidth collectively than many nations do. This is a heavy-duty factory of computing that cranks out a lot of product!
- You handle something new and different everyday. Every day you learn something new or handle something new. It seems kind of daunting but is rather fun. This is a large company with every kind of discipline possible: claims processing, network management, underwriting, sales, IT, legal, advertising/marketing, finance, accounting, statistical analysis, doctors/nurses/counselors, etc. You will talk to people ranging from entry-level claims processors to Senior VPs in a given day. I learned a lot about all the stuff that goes on behind the scenes which makes a large health insurance company function. You can't learn every application there. But if you ask the right way most end users will happily explain how an application or process works. Some are simply glad that someone in the IT department wants to know more about what they do for a living. 
- Company is not going anywhere. This is a large, solid, dependable business. People will always need what they provide. Sure they have hiccups here and there depending on new healthcare legislation but this is a company with a lot of diverse businesses. And the helpdesk was insourced from a contractor a few years ago which many levels of IT management seem to be thrilled with.
- The IT department generally seems well put together. Processes are well-designed, documented and executed. There seems to be a web form, tool or application for EVERYTHING. Very little done on paper or without automation.
- 23 days of annual PTO to use. Days off granted on a first come, first served basis. 
- 99% of calls are from internal customers. You are very rarely dealing with the general public so you don't have to deal with people screaming in your face. Supervisors will generally defend you if there is a problem with a customer.
cons:
- This office is the epitome of "Office Space". Everything is sterile, boring, soulless and in the middle of austere suburban surroundings. It is full of the same meaningless corporate cliches as you see in the movie. It doesn't feel like an IT department. You feel like you work in a customer service call center. You might as well sell magazine subscriptions. The people are boring and lifeless. Everyone and everything is so overly PC it is inhumane. There is very little social interaction. You are very unlikely to ever see your coworkers outside of work. If you do all they talk about is their little universe of resetting passwords for a living. All of the restaurants around this locale will fatten you up quick.
- If you have any kind of personality this place will stifle you quickly and/or they show you the door in no time. They want "yes men" and quiet robots. Granted most of the corporate world is like that but this place brings that concept to the extreme.
- There is little pride here. Someone else on Glassdoor said about UHG, "There is no pride here. Everyone wishes they worked somewhere else. They are all here only to put this on their resume." How true. 
- If you like to use your natural creativity and tech-mindedness to solve interesting problems this place will burn you out fast. You very rarely get to delve deep into problems, your job mostly consists of writing tickets and sending the issues to workgroups. The company wants first-call resolutions but fails to let you do the work you need to do so. The company wants 8 minute resolutions to things that can't be done in 8 minutes. To some people - customers and management alike - all you are is a professional ticket-writer and are treated like such. 
- The lower and middle-level management are not very competent. Most of them have never done this kind of work and are not very qualified to tell you how to do your job. They often have very poor social skills, issues with communication and horrendous writing skills. They don't handle any kind of escalations and you can't go to them for help in the middle of a call.  All they really appear to do is tell you what you did wrong and gab amongst themselves while you have 40 calls in queue. They do their utmost to rub it in your face that they are a notch above you. I've rarely received any help from management types at this place. I am not saying this because I have some general dislike for management, in fact, I truly seek out managers whom I can respect and learn from. I didn't have one at this job. They are all a bunch of dead weight.
- Supervisors try to mask their own incompetence through rampant micromanagement. If they can make some case that their employees are all incompetent and need to be continually managed then it makes them look superior and/or justifies their job. 
- Everything is about ridiculous sets of metrics. Everything. Again this goes back to the customer service vs. helpdesk issue. They care more about how long you were in a call than if you were able to do something to get this person up and working. Show up from lunch a minute late and they will complain about it. Go over 8 mins. in some call and a crazy supervisor will have a fit. They care more about call handling stats than people fixing problems. I always thought helpdesks fixed things.
- EVERYTHING you do is recorded, both your phone audio and your screen video while in a call. It is so 1984 it is ridiculous. Call audio is one thing but the video is just to stalkerish for me. Never do anything that doesn't involve your job. I've never seen such a level of micromanagement. 
- Nobody talks to each other in person or on the phone in the office. It is all done through an instant messaging tool. Sometimes I need to talk to someone face to face. Don't get caught using the IM tool while in a call or you will hear about it. 
- You are chained to your desk the entire day. All you do is answer phone calls. You will forget what it was like to actually repair a computer. You will forget what it was like to walk. There is no face-to-face interaction. You will put on some pounds. 
- Your social interaction is all with people far away. West Coast, East Coast, Texas, down South, even India and the Phillipines. Let's just say you will meet a lot of nice folks but never ever get to have a drink with them. 
- The coffee in this place is the worst coffee that has ever existed. I don't see how it can be legally sold for human consumption. I understand it's free but the nearest real coffee stand is way too far to make it to on a break. 
- They will paint some bright portrait of career advancement. Get in the door and you will find out it was all a pipe dream. You may get out of there but only if you make absolutely ZERO waves and only if you treat your master exactly how they want to be treated. 
- UHG's health benefits, for being a HEALTH INSURANCE company, are pretty lousy. You could work at STARBUCKS slinging coffee and have better health insurance. 
- If you like learning what is happening in other parts of the company look in the newspaper. Granted the place is huge but I saw more current news about UHG in the newspaper business section than in my own internal communications.

review_title: Be prepared to hit the ground running
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Minnetonka, MN
pros:
You have to quickly learn how to navigate through the organization's processes, and not to rely solely on your manager to set you up when you get on board (e.g. log in access to certain accounts, etc). So far my on-boarding has been better compared to my previous employers, where sometimes it takes a couple weeks just to get your workstation set-up and you have to pretty much stare into space during your first week of work because you don't have a computer. In my experience with UHG, my hiring manager pretty much had my basic workstation ready for use right on my first day.

On-boarding process is pretty easy, as you simply get access to a new hire website and it outlines what you need to do within the 1st week, month, and 90 days from your start date. I am pretty particular with that because it's the first few days of work that you typically have to do piles of paperwork and it's easy to miss something, plus I am not a fan of spending time faxing stuff out to HR. Most of the HR stuff is done online.

As far as being a new hire, it has been great, but you really should be able to hit the ground running, as they pretty much throw you in the middle of a project with little or no information at all, and you have to be proactive with a lot of things to keep up. I'm lucky I got a grasp on things when I got pulled into a project. There's still management engagement, and they provide whatever support they can give you (no micromanagement).

Dress codes range from business attire (suit & tie) to somewhat lower (collar, sleeves, slacks). Since I wasn't oriented with that I typically just assess what other people are wearing in the building and decide which is too casual. Definitely not a shirt-and-jeans environment. This is just for their main building, I guess because the executives reside there. It seems that for the other buildings, it's pretty laid-back. They don't have dress code marshals running around, though, so as far as I know as long as you look presentable, you're not going to be in trouble.

The have a high variety of the age range of the employees, which I like. And they are willing to hang out. I have had jobs where it's pretty much go-to-work-and-go-home type, as most of my teammates just up and leave when it hits end of workday for the most part. Here they have times where you either go for a happy hour with the team someplace nearby, or have lunch in a conference room just to chat - even for just an hour. And that's even when they're extremely busy. I appreciate that in the workplace - it makes me feel like I'm part of the team even if I am a newbie. And that motivates me to go to work everyday. They are pretty good at considering your time at work - they don't just throw meeting schedules on your calendar over lunch hours without checking with you. 

It's too early yet to determine how the promotion/performance ratings are being done, so I'll leave that out for the next update.
cons:
Cons are pretty superficial but I'm putting them here anyway...

Their buildings are pretty scattered - I came in a period where hundreds of constructions are going on in the area, so it is crazy trying to navigate between buildings when you have to (they do have an inter-office shuttle service, but still). Hopefully they'll start consolidating their departments into one building so it's easier. Plus, the main building's cafeteria is so much better.

It's not totally a Con, but it's pretty interesting that they don't really orient you firsthand on the dress-code policy, and other house-rules. I don't really care much for having these but I typically had to undergo some orientation about the dress-codes and stuff on my first day. The only orientation they have is more on the employee benefits, important company websites, information management/security policies, sexual harrassment, and insider trading.

I know UHG is driving for "being green", but they need paper plates in their break rooms. Also, they need to work on stocking office supplies. I can't find even the humble push-pin in their stock bin - all I see are folders and printing paper. :)

Their websites need a bit more work because it was a tad confusing for a new hire to navigate through, but once you get used to it it's OK.

job_title: Business Analyst in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
Many talented, collaborative and hard working people. 

Once you're in, you have the opportunity to move within the company, both laterally and up. It's a heads-down work until it's done environment (this is a pro and con, depending what you're used to or looking for). The discount stock option is nice but it is capped. Think of it as a small bonus. 

UHG does give back to the community. There many volunteer events and donation drives throughout the year.
cons:
My advice to anyone looking to join UHG, do your research about the department, team and role you're considering. 

WORK-LIFE-BALANCE does not exist in some, even most areas. During the busy months (plural), it's expected that you could be working 60-70 hrs/week, including evenings and weekends. 

Ask what is the average day like and if there is a busy time during the year, though hiring managers may not be transparent about that so find someone who knows the area that you can talk with offline.

WORKING FROM HOME (telecommute). If it's not an official telecommuter position, the company policy says it's up to the manager to decided if you can work from home or not. So ask the hiring manager (not only the HR recruiter) about their work-from-home policy. Some managers are flexible, and will allow you to leave early to get something done since you'll make it up later. Some may even tell you to take paid time off if you need to go to a parent-teacher meeting at your kid's school or have a doctor's appointment. 

HEALTH BENEFITS Some reviewers said they were good, but that is not true. Many employees were appalled at how bad the health benefits are, especially for 2016 and even posted using their real names on the company intranet, calling out the company and executives. Before you accept an offer, read in detail the health benefit options, specially if you have a family or health issues, as it could hit your pocketbook.

review_title: Your experience at UHC will vary based on where you land in the company
pros: UHC is a huge & complex company, and once you’ve landed a job there, your chances of landing other jobs within the company are greatly enhanced. Not too many years ago, United had an extremely toxic culture (I’ve heard people outside of the company refer to United as the “Evil Empire”) and under Steve Hemsley’s leadership, they’ve done a great job turning that culture around. The company makes a concerted effort to provide a standardized experience across its many business units through a shared culture, and it does a good job of communicating cultural values. Many (although not all) of the  business units fully engage in and support telecommuting or remote roles. Success at United is defined by performance, so if you are a self-starter, this is a great place to work.
cons:
UHC is a huge & complex company, and your experience may be dismal in certain business units or departments. Not all areas of the company live by the cultural values. It will be interesting to see how/whether new CEO Dave Wichman promotes the culture. 

Do not expect career progression by staying in the same line of work or department; promotions rarely occur and you are more likely to move up through applying to a new job in a different part of the company. 

The company talks about diversity but I do not see much racial, ethnic or gender diversity in the Minneapolis headquarters or in the higher echelons. 

The workforce is bifurcated into remote and office-based staff. A surprising number of office-based staff neither support nor make an effort to work with telecommuters. Many positions that could be performed remotely require living in Minneapolis, and while Minneapolis is a lovely city, I prefer living and working in my ethnically & racially diverse warm-weather state.

United is an extremely fiscally conservative company so do not expect it to be on the leading edge of innovation. United is much more adept at being the second or third in to a market by learning from others mistakes and by being extremely detailed and thorough in its follow up approach. 

Another outcome of United’s fiscally conservative approach is selective layoffs after weaker-than-expected performance or (more commonly) after major acquisitions. These are common and predictable. I’ve known many people whose positions were eliminated while United “right-sizes” the balance sheet, only to be hired in a different position sometime later.

-The insurance is cheap, but there is a large deductible.  However, it almost makes up for the difference in premiums.  Years ago before getting into healthcare I paid $200 per month for insurance for my children and myself and had a $500 deductible.  I have the cheapest policy available to my job grade and get the maximum wellness discount and pay about $50 per month with a $2950 deductible.  My rates are about $1800 less, but my deductible is $2450 higher.  However, we have an HSA and the company puts in $1000.  So, I'm paying about $350 less overall if I hit my deductible.  So the insurance isn't that bad if you take advantage of the HSA.  People complain about the insurance, but if you break it down it works out.
cons:
-Most of my pros are cons as well.
-Telecommuting is great, but if I call in sick I'm told I can work at home.  If I'm too sick to come in, I'm probably too sick to work at home.
-Few people work 40 hours per week.  I work at night often and many times work until 2 am, and so do several of my coworkers.  Many hourly people work over 40 hours without overtime pay to get their work done.  The company doesn't force them to work for free, but they have too much work to do and are not allowed to get overtime.  So it's work over or get fired.
-Get as much money going in as you possibly can, because raises and promotions have caps.  For example, the median pay for a level 26 in my area is about 62,000.  Let's say you are hired at a level 24 for 40,000.  The cap for each level increase is 5%, and raises are usually no more than 3%.  If you got a raise at 3% your new salary would be 41,200.  Then if you were promoted to a level 26 you would be making no more than 45,423.  That's nowhere near the average of 62,000, and it would take years of raises to get there.  Do your homework on salaries before accepting a job there, or you will soon be leaving to take a better paying job.  This leads up to my next point.
-It's hard to advance in this company.  Due to the pay restrictions it's hard to get anywhere if you don't start out already up there.  This can also work against you.  I applied for a job exactly like mine at another location but was told I make more than they are willing to pay for the job.  It was the same level and job description, but I would have had to take a paycut.  Go figure that out.
-Management does not communicate.  For example, I got a raise, but I only found out when I saw it on my paycheck.  My review consisted of an email with scores only and no verbiage.  We do not have team meetings or one-on-ones.
-It's hard to get well if you get sick.  You can't take a few days off to get well without getting calls from work or being asked to work at home.This is a healthcare company, but they have to respect for employees when they get sick.  It can actually count against you, because the policy states "Should an employee demonstrate excessive use of unplanned time off or an unacceptable pattern of PTO usage, the employee may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal."  So although you may have 60 hours of PTO saved up, you could lose your job if you got sick too much and had to use it.
-You can only carry over 40 hours of paid time off, and if you leave the company voluntarily you do not get paid for any accumulated time off.  If you are terminated you only get paid for 40 hours of accumulated time off.  But don't think you can turn in your notice and then use paid time off.  Once that resignation is in, you can't take any days off.  So if you think you're going to be leaving, use that time up or lose it.
-This company is just too large to manage properly.  There is not one IT system where data can be retrieved from.  Data is all over the place, and there are different systems that do not interface with one another.
-Very high turnover.  I have come to the conclusion they like it like that.  There is always someone out there who is willing to work for less money in this economy.  Employees are replacable resources and are not valued.

review_title: "Due to our ever changing business needs..."
job_title: User Interface Developer in Boston, MA
pros: Remote work opportunities, but even they are becoming scarce.
cons:
This is my second review at Optum and I wanted to give a bit more detail of my experiences.  I was an Optum employee for around 3 1/2 years, full time and permanent.  I was the second person hired on to the team for which I worked.  I was a UI developer working on a project whose title I needn't disclose.  Towards the end of my time, all the UI work seemed to dry up and everything became heavy on the Java side of development.  Concerned for my position I asked my manager and was told, "the UI work will come back in the form of a complete UI rebuild" and I had nothing to worry about.  

In the downtime, I continued to learn new technologies that would make me more useful to Optum, so when the UI work came back I could hit the ground running.  About a month later I was laid off.  The reasons I was given were "budget cuts" and "lack of UI work".  When I inquired about the UI rebuild work that same manager told me  "it's not happening" and "I just don't know".   Fast forward a month or two later and I find out that the UI work DID in fact return and I also found out that Optum had onboarded a bunch of college grads and new TDP kids.  Lack of work?  Budget cuts?  No.  I was lied to and was let go for no justifiable reason.

The bottom line is this.  Despite how upper management touts about how Optums first priority is its people, they certainly are not.  Optum would rather employ kids fresh out of school who lack real world experience than industry veterans who know what they're doing.  I was told of one particular TDP kid who was caught regularly napping on company time about 2 - 3 hours a day.  He still has a job with Optum.

They brag about all the billions of dollars they make, while ex-employees like myself wonder how they're going to pay their mortgages until they find new work.

review_title: It's not who you are, it's who you know
pros: UHG has a very large presence in Minnesota, specifically the western suburbs of Minneapolis. Their size allows for many *potential* openings (more on this later), and can look on a resume. While the health/dental insurance is flat out poor, the company is generous with PTO. UHG is also very progressive with telecommuting arrangements (whereas most companies are still in the dark ages with this, and see working from as too revolutionary).
cons:
As the headline states, it's not who you are it's who you know. While it's true that this can be said of many companies and organizations, it is especially true at UHG. Being friends with the hiring manager will fast track you to a new position far quicker than actually being the most qualified applicant. In other words, people with mediocre experience and skills (but may have had a few happy hours with the hiring managers) are promoted, NOT the most qualified applicant. This is very frustrating.

Even in the darkest economy, this company has thousands of job openings in the TC metro area alone. This speaks volumes about the company's ability to retain talent. External candidates are almost always perceived as being more hopeful and "exotic" than internal candidates, who are typically seen as "plain". As long as the hiring department can afford it, external candidates are paid whatever they ask for regardless of their current salary. But once you're in the door, you have no leverage with negotiating future salaries, and your new salary is based entirely on your current salary regardless of what others are making in the same position. The company would rather have people leave to make a competitive salary somewhere else than just pay their employees what they'll end up paying an external candidate anyway (i.e. someone with little/no direct knowledge of the position, may or may not work out, may or may not bail after a month due to a better offer, etc.).

Long story short, make very sure that the salary you settle on is truly what you're after because it will not go up even after years in the same position. And if you get promoted to a higher level position, the increase will be noticeably less than what you would receive from a different company. Unless you regularly go out with your boss and buy them drinks, or flat out kiss their @$$.

review_title: Micromanagement and being inundated with meetings reigns supreme here.
pros: Salary, bonus are pretty good. Vacation time given is great.
cons: Prefacing this by saying, this is a huge company and employment experiences may vary greatly depending on within which segment of this company you work. That said, from my experience, if you can't think for yourself and need your hand held by your manager, Optum is the job for you. Micromanagement is the name of the game where I work. You may have otherwise proven yourself perfectly competent but always remember that your manager knows best and will see to it that you do everything you are supposed to do and when it is supposed to be done and that it is done their way! Instead of outlining tasks and giving employees accountability for seeing to it that these tasks are completed accurately and within a timely manner, you are subjected to micromanagement on various levels. And as far as vacation goes, UHG is very generous in my opinion. But local PTO policy leaves much to be desired. They have made so many rules as to when you can and can’t use PTO, such as limiting the time you are able to take off during summer months. And they have twice within the last 18 months put a block on any new PTO requests during certain time periods because of upcoming training. Training and meetings are one of the most important things to local Optum management. The majority of my coworkers work in the field. The local office is not our “office” and long drives to the local corporate office coupled with hours in a meeting makes patient management difficult. Despite that fact, mandated meetings in person at the local office are frequent and, when considering what information was given to you at the meeting, oftentimes longer than necessary. Much of the information does not require in-person attendance. I'm not sure why they even bother putting the actual word "mandatory" in the meeting notification—it goes without saying. Local management is aware of various technology available to them for information dissemination and the creation of a learning environment that works for all, but they apparently refuse to embrace this technology. Instead they insist on wasting reams of paper (and expensive ink), gallons of gas getting to an often distant office, the cost to corporate for mileage to and/or from the office just to tell us things that could be told via email, powerpoint or webex or a myriad of other medium. Wasteful and not ecologically sound.

review_title: Lack of Career Growth...Surrounded by Dead weights
job_title: Software Engineer in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
-Good work life balance
-Generous PTO (23 days/year), 4.5% 401k match (100% match for first 3%, then 50% match up to another 3%)
-Easy work
-Nice coworkers
-Cool building
-New technology in some area of the company
-Amazing job security because there are many low performers 
-Good stepping stone company
cons:
-Below average pay...you may be hired at a fair/competitive rate, but the yearly raises are not very competitive for people with technical background. Below the industry standard raise of 3%. People will get a max of 2% raise for an outperforming review. Hence, most of the employees here do the bare minimal as an average review will get you 1.2-1.8% raise. After one year, most newcomers will realized it is not worth working hard for the .0X% difference.

-There are many dead weights on my team. At least 80% of my team (20+ developers) is floating around doing less than average amount of points per sprint. Some developers can slide by fixing a defect for a single null pointer exception over the duration of 1-2 weeks...others would call in WFH, but with their status show up as 'away' or 'offline' if anyone bothers to look on Jabber (the internal messaging app we use here)

-Management will continue to blindly hire more developers because the existing ones won't do the work. I have difficulty understanding why low performers are allowed to stay and even promoted in some cases over valuable teammates.

-There are a lot of favoritism in this organization. Your performance matters very little in the yearly review. You will get a higher mark if you know the manager and hanging out with them during happy hours.

-We are moving toward a full agile environment, so WFH is discouraged. At the same time, there are not enough desks for all developers who comes in to office

-Most managers do not care about your career growth

-The culture training are mocked by most attendees as they know it's more symbolic than substance. Our culture values cannot thrive due to the limitations at the system/organization level

-The yearly performance review grades the team on a normal curve. So, even if everyone performed really well, there will always be losers and winners. Contrary to what they taught us in culture trainings. Good talents do not stay more than 2 years here...unless they are also favored by management

job_title: Registered Nurse in Maryland Heights, MO
pros:
-Compensation
-Culture (outside of management)
-Coworkers/work environment (when it does not include management)
cons:
I am excited to be able to share this review with you, and thank you for taking the time to read. I am an experienced Registered Nurse and began my time with UHC/Optum thrilled to have a work-from-home position specifically for the flexibility and independence. I met with one of the managers at the Maryland Heights, MO location and LOVED her. As time went on, I found myself compromising A LOT and feeling like I was in a bad marriage. As mentioned previously, I wanted the flexibility. When I first started, I was told I would have three weeks of training, which turned into nine weeks. This was frustrating for me as I have many other commitments outside of work, and by the time I actually had things communicated to me, I was already too invested. Had I have known this, I would have never taken the position initially.

Training was 8-5 M-F and was inflexible. Then, on a Friday, we were told training would be 7a-3p the following Monday to accommodate someone who worked on the East coast. Here I was to be flexible, yet had to change around my schedule completely without advanced notice. The nine weeks of training was then pointless as UHC did a bait-and-switch and split the class up into ¼ nurse triage and ¾ nurse triage and insurance. Did I mention we then had a new manager? This happened at the end of training…again, once we were all invested. Being flexible, once again, I kept a positive attitude and began taking the phone calls. The calls ranged from “let me transfer you to member services” to “let me explain the donut hole.” I knew I was not a member service representative, but I still kept going because I told myself nurses can help people get to where they need to go, right? I was yelled at, ridiculed, and maybe received 20 total triage calls from members when I worked there for five months. Not to mention, more skills were added which included Medicaid patients who I needed to transfer to Medicaid customer service. How is this nursing when 75% of calls were transferred to another department and members were not being cared for at all? 


There was no flexibility. If you needed to leave the desk for 5-10 minutes, you would receive a very passive aggressive group email reminding everyone of the telecommuter rules. Where is this so-called flexibility? We were chained to our desks for 8 or 10-hour shifts.

Now for the independence. We were watched constantly. Our group jabber was watched by someone at all times to ensure we were doing our jobs since we were Registered Nurses with licenses and could not be trusted. Let’s talk about the value that was added to our role since we are one of the most trusted professions out there. We can save lives, but, at UHC, we have to be watched. Talk about an invasion of privacy and feeling devalued. 

My favorite part was when we had a meeting about a survey we were coerced into answering positively as this was how management was paid their bonus. We heard that on particular questions, “we were never given less than 100%”, so if we do now, that makes us look bad. Talk about being desperate for your bonus. 

After all is said and done, I decided it was best for me to part ways. I received a phone call days later from my so-called “Manager” who asked what UHC could do for me. I was told that he would work with upper management to make this happen because I was so well-liked and “one of their best new-hires.” I waited an entire week for an email and instead received a box in the mail to return my things. No explanation. No email. No “I am sorry.” No exit interview. Nothing. I then wrote a second email asking him to explain what was going on and still no response. Then, I emailed my former manager who obviously knows what is going on there who must have forwarded my email to him. He then got back to me right away with this email:

 “Shipping boxes and labels have been ordered and will be arriving at your residence for you to send all equipment back in. An email was sent Monday with this information included, I apologize if you did not receive it. If you have any questions, please contact me.”

Yet another bait-and-switch with UHC. No word about me staying there. No apology. Nothing. I felt like a number in that cold, corporate environment where my hard work was unnoticed and undervalued.

ZERO work/life balance. To keep a lean budget, we have a skeleton staff. Even if we doubled our staff, we would still have to work at least 50+ hours per week. We are told to suck it up, which leaves no time for family. Still expected to finish a project on time/on budget, even though we could work 24/7 and still not finish (expectations are ridiculous) Lots of turnover in my dept because of this. However, I think this philosophy is based on dept management and can vary. 
I've been with the company for 12 years, and it is almost impossible to get a job in another dept, even with glowing yearly reviews. HR tells you to "promote" yourself and stresses you are responsible for your own career growth, which I agree with. However, they could help by throwing you a bone/interview once in a while. I applied for at least 15 jobs I know I'm qualified for and have only landed  two interviews. 
I think UHC has good intentions with the United culture roll out. However, it's difficult to follow the culture when management does not. I've actually witnessed a culture ambassador scream at someone and tell the employee she is an idiot. 
Yearly Vital Signs (reverse review) is a joke. Even though it claims to be "anonymous", no one I know believes it. Yeah, it's a third party who handles the data, but we still don't trust management with it. Reverse reviews are used for two things- for management to show their bosses how awesome they are or to lump their employees over the head with. I've yet to see any positive outcomes from VS-just a bunch of empty promises, "yeah, we'll get a committee together and work on that for next year." Great-just what we need;  ANOTHER meeting fixing YOUR management probems (it's always the employees who have to be on these committees). Sometimes they actually do fix the problem, but most the questions are so vague, it's difficult to fix anything significant. "Do you like upper management" (or some form of that question). Uh, I don't know. I don't deal with them on a daily basis. "Do you like your physical work environment?" Heck yes! I'm a telecommuter! I also think the questions are written in a way that data can be manipulated when pulling a report.

cons: Low pay, high taxes. pros:
I wish I had more positive things to say about the company, but as a general thing, the best parts of this job were specific to the Bothell office. The people I worked with and worked for directly were, with few exceptions, pretty good or even great. We had a good local culture because we were somewhat distant from the home office and largely autonomous, at least initially.

The one thing the company did right was that, when we lost the huge contract that sustained most of our office, they managed to keep us employed for a couple more years with a big project.

The company seems willing to let a lot of people telecommute though, which is always a plus.
cons:
Every time something came down from higher-level management, it was bad news for us.

Our medical benefits got worse every year, and they weren't great to start with. (As an aside, it's pretty galling to work for a health insurance company that provides such mediocre health insurance to its employees. Almost every plan I worked on was better than mine.)They slashed our benefit for diabetes medications at just about the same time they were running a big diabetes awareness campaign.

They implemented a combined claims/customer service department for their newer contracts, but it's such a miserable department to work in that everyone who transferred to it regrets it. No one working in our office would apply for openings there, so they had to hire outside the company.

And then there were little things like "normalizing" policies for PTO and bonuses across the company, and those were inevitably worse for us.

The company also puts out a bunch of initiatives about caring about its employees, particularly their health, but it rings pretty hollow given our non-competitive pay and poor benefits.

All that is without getting into the company trying to use its employees as part of its propaganda machine when they were fighting against the ACA. Every employee was given pre-written post cards to send to Congress decrying the ACA.

They can insult you in very condescending way and your manager or supervisor won't do anything. They will just put you in training for "soft skills". 

Seat: Cubicle, squad of 4 . You will have 3 other team mates who speak same language as you.

Hours: 7-3:20, 9:30-6 or 10:30-7. You may not have a shift of your choice because you must discuss and have approval from your squad. Max 2 open shift per person. 

Time off: Black out periods: February- May , October-December. Your PTOs request can be denied or you have to check if anybody in your squad is vacay. 
  *February- May: You are not allowed to leave your desk or lock out for break/lunch until your team mates arrive or return. 

Volume: Up to 50+ customer service call AND  2-3 interpreting calls per day during Oct-Dec
  * Interpreting call may take up to 2 hours each.

Metrics: Quality assurance is there to catch you because if you are not 100% every month, the company can reason NOT to rise your pay (Max rise is about four percent) .

Career advancement: DIFFICULT 
   *You need a "release" from your manager, again 'release' may not be granted during black out periods mentioned above. Other departments may want you but you can be stuck and won't be transferred if your opportunity is during this time. If you send out application internally, your manager will  always and automatically be notified. Most internal departments have high standard and low pay grade. They ask for a lot of skills but not compensated enough.

review_title: It's a job that could be a career if UHG would make some changes.

review_title: Community & State: Beware of working for Big Names that have DEAD-END positions
job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in Sugar Land, TX
pros:
As far as benefits I would say its not that bad: 
Health Insurance cost lower than others
Competitive 401k
Stock Purchase Plan
Generous PTO after 5 years
Life/Work Balance
Ability to work from home
cons:
Yes, the benefits are good because they claim to care.  But they only care so much.  There are no real opportunities for those without medical degrees (BSN, LVN, RN, PhD, Dr) at least in Sugar Land, TX.  Everything else comes second or last to those without these types of degrees.  Mentoring and networking is nonexistent-tried to get a senior employee (C-Level executive) to assist me in getting into (or at least learning about ) an executive track, she snickered and gave me the usual "you should apply online" shpeal.  They will promote nurses who can barely type or design a workflow to lead a team of administrative coordinators and label them Health Service Managers simply because they can make medical decisions (even if they have no real influence on a members health)-which renders that reasoning as insane.  Yeah, we get it,  you have to be certified to be a nurse, but not to be a dept. manager.  Those who aren't registered nurses and lead teams have proven more capable than their registered counterparts and it's sad.   Administrative people get severely underpaid as compared to other areas and companies who offer the same position.  I went in as a Clinical Administrative Coordinator (Clinical means nothing here), I left as a Clinical Administrative Coordinator with less employable years... The only thing I really learned on-the-job was not to fall for this kind of dead end job again.

By being employed here, despite not getting paid or treated like one, you are considered to be in the same capacity as a public official regardless of your influence or position.  With that in mind, you cannot accept goods or gifts from vendors that might violate state anticorruption/fairness rules.  You cannot get any real bonuses (monetary value exceeding a certain amount) that might be deemed too costly to taxpayers.  Again, they treat you like a public official where their wages and information can be looked up, however, yours really isn't-your not a public official-and your really just a nobody that's being taken advantage of.  And they love to use this as an excuse to exclude you from getting a raise/bonus.  

If you love being in one position and not learn anything aside from what you already know, this is the job for you!  If you love being looked over and ignored for promotions, you've found the job of your dreams.  If you like repetitive work day in and day out, you need to apply right away!  I say this with a certain amount of humor but in all seriousness, it is not a job for those with aspirations to move up the corporate ladder.  If this is you I encourage you to look elsewhere.

review_title: Do not plan to start a career here!

cons:
I spent four years trying to work my way up at UHG/Optum. I had 6 different managers, and they kept changing my title and work depending upon what was needed by team. I cooperated, but this hindered my personal development since I continually had to start over and learn new projects and roles. I continued to get positive reviews from my managers, but I reached the ceiling of my pay scale and was unable to get a raise for the last two years.

I took a lateral move to work at Optum, but I experienced the same uncertainty and changes that plagued UHC. I spent nearly two years at the top of my pay grade trying to network and apply for jobs the next level up. I had no support or guidance from managers on how to develop my career even though my yearly reviews were always positive.

Finally, they made major reorganizations last summer, and moved me again to another team. These moves were so poorly thought out that they released the manager in charge but still continued with his dramatic changes. This whole winter had been frustrating for my  division, and finally we received word in February that they were doing another reorganization to fix the mistakes made in the summer. They gave my team two weeks notice and released all of us. When I spoke with the Senior Director, he placed all blame on the previously fired manager, and told me he would work with us to find new positions. I applied for multiple positions, yet I never received the assistance he promised to give. I did hear that they rehired the manager who made the poor choices last August, while the rest of us on the team are struggling to find work as the economy heads into a recession, and UHG stock continues to do well.

review_title: UHG offers plenty of variety and opportunity, but suffers from its growing pains internally.
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for UHG include the variety of work - the company is so big that there are lots of different types of work to do, the plethora of job opportunities in the various business segments - there are dozens and dozens of office locations across all the business segments, the understanding of most management types for balancing of work and life, and the Rewarding Results program that rewards top-performers in the company. cons: UnitedHealth Group has grown primarily due to corporate acquisitions. Because of this, the variety of technologies used at UHG is expansive and there are strong efforts to standardize and consolidate those technologies. Unfortunately, these efforts to standardize often trample over efforts to innovate and introduce new technologies or means of solving business problems.  For some of the same reasons, communication of assets, ongoing efforts, technology innovation, and development efforts is very poor.  System and work-effort redundancy runs rampant within the company, even though top management acknowledges it and recognizes that it needs to be resolved.  Another downside to working at UHG is that the company's office locations span the country so that nearly all meetings that cross business segments or application teams are held via conference call.  If a person prefers to work face-to-face with his or her peers, they may find it very hard to adjust.

review_title: Expect the unexpected... and a little frustration.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Greensboro, NC
pros:
Pay can be good if you're a very driven person.  More so if you have an undergraduate degree.  If you can keep up your performance goals you'll usually get a decent raise each year.  

Even if you don't plan on staying in the health insurance field you can still learn a LOT about how claims are submitted and processed and how different plans and benefits work - useful to know when choosing or using your insurance.  

Some employees are given great opportunities to travel and learn more skills.

Most of your coworkers remember what it was like to climb the steep learning curve and will help you.  Networking with your peers pays well.
cons:
Expect change constantly.  UHG is too big for the right hand to know what the left is doing and yet continues to grow and acquire new companies.  Integration of other companies into the fold has left UHG a patchwork of mis-matched systems and expectations.  

Expect under-training and continual negative feedback.  Management expects employees to know vast amounts of information and use up to 15 programs on a call with a customer.  Of course that call better be short and accurate and pleasant and everything else.  It can be draining when you're expected to field anywhere from 60 - 120+ calls in a day.  On top of that, customer service reps are expected to keep abreast of updated programs, policies, procedures, medical technology and medical terminology "between calls."  Oft times, there is no between call time.

Expect less than stellar vacation time, frequent schedule changes and possibly mandatory overtime.  Time off is bidded on based on seniority, performance in various areas and sometimes just on being a "pet" of your manager.  An employee may be exceeding their metrics and goals but will probably not get the time off they ask for - even if you ask for it months in advance.  Bidding is done several times a year and is basically a circus.  Employees are basically punished for not exceeding performance goals (even if you're meeting all goals and show up on time, etc. and have no write-ups or warnings you can and probably will be bumped to a worse schedule if you are not exceeding in most if not all areas.  Favoritism is rampant.  If you're exceeding all your metrics then you're making your manager look good - you're also contributing to their bonus.  If you're maybe not hitting in all performance areas then you'll bring down your manager's bonus and that tends to make them not like you.  Or maybe they just like you for whatever reason (going to the same church seems to be a big asset).  In that case you'll probably get preferential treatment (access to promotions and perks).  I've been on both sides of this - this is not at all professional and possibly unethical.  Overtime is often mandatory.  There will be some weeks where you work more than 50 hours a week sometimes for months at a time.  Can't work overtime?  Can't keep you, sorry.

review_title: UHCBS- Cobra/Exchange/ Direct Bill/ Employer-Broker/ Reimbursement - member and employer
pros: In chaos there is always overtime.
cons:

Pay is below industry standards.

Mgmt has the expectation that 1 rep should be able to take any call that comes in even if you hadn't taken that skill in months. 
Reps cant keep up with all the changes for every skill, unrealistic expectation.
The systems are extremely outdated and extremely slow because there are too many people using them and the servers cant support the traffic. 
Mgmt has advised to write memos for customer accounts on a word memo pad and type them into the memo system on your break or lunch because the memo system keeps freezing or has extreme lagging.
The call center reps aren't given the tools to correct any issue, and there are tons of them. All the reps can do is answer the calls and route to Operations. 
The turn around times for resolution are never met, which creates multiple call backs for the customer. 
UES -voice of the customer- are at an all time low for the department, due to issues the reps cant control or fix. 
Customer payments don't post to the accounts, reps can see credit card payments- aren't given the tools to see-
 Coverage's do not update to reflect active on the benefit side, so the customer cant use the coverage it shows as terminated. 
Tickets routed to finance can be open for weeks and still not assigned to a rep to resolve.
Customer leave feed back that they don't like the process, and mgmt response was the rep has to turn the call around no matter what the issue is, they are not to leave the call unhappy.
As a consumer, if I paid 1200.00 for coverage I should be able to use my health insurance and not wait 5 business days or more for the coverage's to be activated. 
Employers call with questions about their invoices which we cant answer- cant see the employer invoices- and have to route to finance for more insight. This confuses the Employers because they are given our number on the invoice to call with any questions.
Basically the call center reps can only answer the phone and route to operations, they cant fix, change or correct anything for the customer /employer. Micro mgmt to the highest degree, and this directly effects the customer who IS the most important factor. 
Freeze in department, not allowed to post out to any other position outside of the department because we have extremely high turn over, not enough people to answer the calls. It will be almost a year the freeze is on and no end in sight. 
Mgmt has made comments if people want to leave the department they aren't loyal and can quit.

pros:

Brown nosers apply here. It's not about how much hard work you put in to this company its about who you know. I've been to a few different departments in this company and the brown nosers will always be promoted. If you work hard and do extra work management will want you to stay in your position since you are the core of your department. The cafeteria food is bad and overly priced. There is hardly ever any kind of selection of food here. 

People cant seem to walk in a straight line or walk directly in your path here, making you move. Either that or people like walking directly on your heels with loud shoes. Watch out for packs of slow walkers or brown nosers who walk with their laptop in one hand to look important. 

This company loves big words like stratification. Look up a bunch of big words and throw them out during meetings regardless of the words meaning. Oh and if you are called on during a conference call say "Bill, and keep me honest." That way some of the blame goes to Bill if things go wrong. 

This company is a smokers paradise. Even though this company has strict no smoking policies on campus (which includes the parking garage) there is a designated smoking area, complete with ash trays at the bottom of each parking garage. Don't even try to complain when your coworker comes back from their smoke break smelling like an ashtray, HR will give you the run around. Heck, my coworker openly chews tobacco at his desk and management turns a blind eye. 

If your boss makes you do a project, bring on the hard workers of your department to do the actual work but take all the credit. When it comes to doing your part of the project say things like "I think we need to come together as a team to look at this issue." That way the team has to finish your part of the project, and you can go back to browsing Facebook. Look for easy things like already made newsletters online where you enter the words and the template does all the design, you will look amazing in your managers eyes! This company loves its newsletters/blogs. 

If you are going to work here my advice is to get out and look for other employment if you aren't promoted within 2 years. The company culture is deeply rooted in favoritism, and hardly ever rewards hard work.

review_title: Sinking Ship at the Lewin Group (Consulting subsidiary of Optum)
pros:
-Great PTO (Everyone regardless of level gets 23 days). After 5 years of employment you get 25 PTO days. 5 day max rollover to next year so it's a use it or lose it policy.

cons:
-Toxic senior leadership made some communication mistakes this year and that trickled down the levels with limited explanations to changes in firm policy and longtime CEO's  "resignation." Leadership has tunnel vision only to profits and billing rather than looking at the bigger picture of attrition and staff turnover. 
-Junior staff viewed as replaceable parts and not as human beings. 
-Lack of support ($  + time) for professional development at all levels.  For staff supporting analytics and policy projects we need devoted time to keep up with trends and skill sets in our fields but leadership from Lewin/Optum makes it difficult to make it a priority with client work. 
-Fire drill task turnarounds and "all hands on deck" mentality that becomes a weekly or daily occurrence due to bad project management leadership. 
-Mid-level staff (Consultants and Senior Consultants) are overburdened with both project and business development tasks that burnout is not uncommon. I would often see staff online after dinner on weekdays through the evenings regularly. That expectation of hard work with no substantial pay increase (average annual increase ~1%) or promotion has gotten out of hand. 
-While most people are generally nice, there are also young staff that hoard work to increase their utilization rates and will use your word against you when it comes to review periods. There are some passive aggressive personalities that are learned from senior leadership that are hard to shake off and unfortunately the junior staff feel that they need to act similarly in order to rise up the ladder. It's a shame because not everyone is like that across the firm but those that seem to be favored for promotions are toxic personalities. The majority of the great senior management has left between 2017-2018.

review_title: If I were to choose theme songs for UHG, they would be:  “It’s Never Enough” & “More-More-More”
pros: A steady paycheck. That’s about all the pros I can think of.
cons:
It would be nice if the #1 insurer in the world (And a Fortune 5 company) actually offers affordable insurance to its employees.  The plan is to keep deductibles so high that you will not use your so-called benefits. 
Telecommute positions only mean that UHC will gladly accept the employee working 24/7 in order to meet the goals imposed upon the employee knowing full well that the goals are unattainable even with a 50-hour work week that is the real norm. Salaried people beware, this, along with all your deductions on your paycheck, will drive your net pay to practically nothing. Not to mention the deterioration of your health from sitting at your desk for too many hours each day — if you were in an office, you would be more apt to get up and move around. 
If you are on a team, it is very hard to get time off when you need or want it and it is impossible to take time off for a family event that may pop up. Much overtime is required before taking scheduled time off and even more overtime is required when you return from taking time off in order to regain control of your work queue because the already overworked coworkers cannot help (even though they are assigned to help). 
The final blow: Omega.  This software “God” tracks every second of your work day. Click when you start a case, click when you get interrupted, click when you get back to the case, click when you end the case, click when you go to a meeting, click when you end the meeting, click when you take a bio break, click when you inhale (well, almost).  “They” say it is merely a tool to help the employee improve their work production.  I believe it is a tool for gathering data to feed into artificial intelligence (AI).  UHG is heavily investing in AI technology; this means MANY jobs will be obsolete in the near future. 
No regard is given to the US employees — it’s a thankless job to be sure.
