review_title: Too many mergers, health care reform and the economy has been the downfall
pros:
The pay seems to be commensurate with the industry.
In the hay day, bonues, profit sharing, and stock options were exceptional.
Being a part of a fortune 50 corporation provides a lot of economies of scale that allow the corporation to give its employees discounts through other retailers (like auto companies and apple)
The name looks good on resume
cons:
There are 75000 employees spread across 50 states.
The coporation is based in MN, so it is MN centric. If you are working outside of MN you are out of the loop.  If you were an acquisition and not part of the original UHC proper, you are looked down upon and treated like a red-headed step child.

There is NO advancement.  You either have to apply for a higher grade job in another department or leave the company entirely (lose seniority and time off) and return for any advancement.  

The company does not value loyal, knowledgable and experienced employees.  Employees are not a part of any solutions.  It is a top down, dictatorship management style.  Changes are made on the fly.  The changes are poorly delivered if even properly communicated.  Usually, via email.  No one is brought in at the beginning of the talks, so the decisions are not well thought out or vetted which results in terrible execution, duplication of work and great inefficiencies.

The economy has required the company to "downsize" employees and make the rest do more with less. Even though Health care reform has increased the workload by leaps and bounds.  There have been little or no raises, and none in the forseeable future as payroll comes out of the 20% of the medical loss ratio calculation that the feds have place on health insurance companies.

review_title: Very political in nature, depends on who you know.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Golden Valley, MN
pros:
Pay and PTO was fine.
Most employees were very helpful and did the best they could given their workload.  My dept had wonderful employees - dedicated and hardworking!
Benefits OK but not great.
cons:
Very, very (!) political environment.  If someone higher up doesn't like you, you are done.  If you give your opinion and it doesn't agree with theirs, you're done.  Even when it's your job to point out possible future issues (so they can be avoided), middle and upper management won't like it and you'll pay.  Best to just agree or brown-nose.

Also, the number of layoffs were incredible - our (smallish - 200 employee) company was purchased by OptumHealth and within 3 -4 years all but 3-4 front line employees had been laid off or had their positions eliminated. (This was how long it took to migrate our original company's software into the UHG platform)

The only ones to stay were the managers someone in Optum's management liked but even management has high turnover - they only stay for a few years and get tired of the back-stabbing that goes on.

One of the worse changes that occurred was HR's decision to go to a bell-curve method of 'grading' employees.  Even if a manager had only 5 employees and they all did a spectacular job, only 1 or 2 would be rated as outstanding, 1 had to be rated as 'needing improvement' and the rest were rated as average.  
I think this method was installed so raise allocations could be justified to the gov't (or to hold off unionization) but it would have been better to give high ratings to everyone doing great work and not tie raises to a 1:1 ratio with their rating.  It only makes sense that someone at the top of their pay range wouldn't get as high a percentage increase as someone at the bottom of the same range who was also doing a great job.  Employees aren't stupid - they would understand that. 

Statistically speaking, a bell curve only holds true when it included thousands and thousands of test subjects but practically speaking, no one wanted to rate all their employees as  'bad' just so you can rate all yours 'great, even if true. That rating method is VERY demoralizing!

cons:
1) Culture - UHG has a renewed focus on Compassion, and at times they forget about Compassion and revert back to the old way of doing things where everything was Stats based. 
2) Unproductive Policies - UHG is all about SOP and Job Aids, which is nice, however many times the policy's don't always reflect a logical way to solve the problem. I think this is something that the company is working on, however with over 1000 different SOP's and Job Aids it's going to take awhile. 
3) Communication - UHG has many different departments and sub-departments with no real map of how those departments work together. For instance Health Advisors deal with claims and benefits all day, however when something needs to go to Clinical Services, Clinical Services sends the info right back stating they can't take care of the issue since they don't have all the info needed. So the send it back to the originator and they have to start all over again, and this keeps happening until someone at Clinical Services takes the time to handle the issue. This hole situation could have been avoided if the Health Advisor has access to the information that CS needs before they start a new case. But instead when you attempt to access the information all you get is the red error message of death.

pros:
-Great health benefits.  

-People of the same "rank" as you tend to be supportive, even during rough times.  

-A lot of people who were there from the start of the company really viewed their coworkers as family, and the lingering sense of belonging was nice while it lasted.

-Nice kitchens, free Keurig.  

-Remote work is available and the systems in place are very reliable if you choose to do that.

-I rarely (though not never) felt pressured to commit to overtime, so that plus the remote options mean that work-life balance is pretty consistently good.  

-They tend to do little mini-party things pretty regularly where they bring in caterers to the office and try to keep morale up.

-A lot of pro-social programs like a pretty heavy-handed annual charity drive where the company matches your funds.
cons:
Ouch.  Where to start?  

On the macro level:
Since being acquired by UHG, the company has dropped all pretenses of caring about employees.  From ridiculous office relocations to mass layoffs despite a hugely profitable year (seriously, $100 million+ in the black, as they so proudly keep relaying to us while simultaneously handing out more pink slips), the upper management has made it clear that their mission is to shed employees through attrition so they can avoid the bad press and severance costs associated with further layoffs.  There is also a disgusting amount of corporate doublespeak.  Despite the fact that the company fired a great number of employees and then rehired international teams at lower wages to do the same jobs, oh no, it's NOT outsourcing--it's "building a global team."  Getting an answer or an internal policy change from middle/upper management is like getting an act of Congress.  They are sluggish and unresponsive to a changing market, and the upper echelons are just business drones who clearly are there to wield an axe for cost-reduction when a surgeon's scalpel is called for.

On the micro level:
-Training was largely insufficient.  It's often left in the learner's hands to know which questions to ask, which is a recipe for disaster.

-The corporate structure is extremely convoluted, so it takes several years of experience just to know which department to go to with an issue.  It's not uncommon to get an email that's been forwarded literally 5 or 6 times between managers while they're just looking for the right department to handle something, so issues can occasionally go unchecked for long periods.  (This is exacerbated by the sluggishness of upper management which was previously described.)

-As part of the above issue, work is distributed extremely unevenly between teams.  Some teams will be struggling to keep the tide at bay while others are twiddling their thumbs for 2 weeks straight.  Projects can almost always be chopped up and divided, but the middle managers don't seem to have a grasp of the systems in place well enough to do so efficiently.  Great ideas about workflow redistribution are sent to "committee hell" and essentially pocket vetoed.

-Related to workload, there is a strict performance metric system that breaks down everything you do into a quantifiable chunk, and this affects your performance reviews and quarterly bonuses.  This fundamentally discourages employees from going above and beyond in any task, because no matter how well you do something, you'll only get X amount of time for it.  Also, your mileage may vary on this point, but I found it existentially disturbing to have everything I do compressed into a context-free numeric percentage goal of a target, without regard for the quality of my output.  If you're the robotic cerebral type, you might find this refreshing--you will always know exactly how far ahead or behind you are compared to expectations... but if you like to really dig into projects and take care of details (like I do), this system can be absolutely maddening.

-There is occasionally a weird obsession with rank and structure, so it feels a little like a cliquey high school at times--"Ugh.  Becky, will you remind Andrea to tell Samantha that I'm totally NOT talking to her right now?"  If you email a person directly when you should have gone somewhere else in the chain, that person won't reply to your email; they'll forward it to their supervisor, who forwards it to YOUR supervisor, who sends you a Bill Lumbergh-ian email (yeah, Office Space reference, but it's appropriate here) gently reminding you of the chain of command.   This might be departmentally local, but it's... strange.  Kind of surreal that real-life adults actually act this way outside of a Mike Judge movie.

-Promotions and raises are nonexistent, pretty much company-wide, unless you're an executive.  In the time I've worked here, my income has actually dropped compared to when I started because of changes to the bonus structure and overtime policies.

review_title: There's More To Employment Than Salary
pros:
Optum is fast-paced and challenging.  There is ample opportunity to test your skills and move up the ranks.

The pay is competitive and there are many perks and benefits (401K match, life insurance, health insurance and wellness programs).
cons:
There were many cons that the pros could not mitigate.  Management is quite unfeeling. If you like a company (or at least your department) to have a "family" feel, a team atmosphere, this is not the place. While most companies are not the place to bring personal issues, Optum could care less when you have responsibilities outside of work.  I missed every important event in my child's life and the funeral of a close friend while I worked there. Once you reach a certain level, be prepared to take work home with you most evenings, including weekends.

The onboarding process was 3 months of sheer boredom. My boss gave me permission to complete some online courses I was taking at a local community college, that's how slow my "training" period was.  Then when training was over, the avalanche of work began. As I became more familiar with the job and the wealth of online training materials available, I wondered why they waited to give me the training materials after I became so busy I didn't have time for them.

Lastly, as the months commenced, I found out that my department had a very high turn over rate, including a number of people who walked out in the middle of the day or left in the evening never to return.  I wish I had known that before I started working there.

You get small discounts at diff companies once you're hired. They donate to charities but that's also a tax write off
cons: Can't use the bathroom or get a drink of water without using your break, they use an old DOS system that leaves room for error, you get internal audits if you make a small or large mistake and it goes against you. They are constantly changing documentation for COB reps to follow so it's almost impossible to get a good flow of work going. They also don't ask reps for their input before "improving documentation". They tell you your helping the company with savings as your job but that's just code for making the higher ups richer. Managers are never available because they are literally in meetings all day. UHC/Optum prides themselves on diversity but there are no persons of color or from different countries in the COB management dept. in Frederick. You are timed to death for everything literally and if you aren't constantly typing, clicking etc then that makes your stats go down too. If your stats go down you don't qualify for the quarterly bonus. Little to no interaction with coworkers unless asking a Senior rep for assistance . Corporate constantly increases team goals for higher production even if a team struggled to make their goal the month prior. Hiring process takes at least a month if they're interested so be prepared to wait if you can. You can only have 3-4 unplanned absences etc in a rolling year or you'll be put on corrective action if you get more. So ppl with kids or health issues etc can only have an emergency or get sick 3-4 times a year basically unless you have FMLA. Health insurance is crapola... To me that shows you don't value your employees enough to offer them better insurance since you're a healthcare insurance company and you want us to be healthy and show up to work. They want to train and up skill you but no pay increase. At least 10 hours of mandatory over time is being requested each week. We get burnt out so easily trying to fulfill this request.

pros: I was in the Broomfield office when Optum first acquired it.  It was a great place to work and very employee friendly.
cons:
They did their own version of Scrum and called in OSAM (Optum Scaled Agile 
Methodology ).  It was pure waterfall but those who drank the Kool-Aid insisted was Agile.  Its no better than most IT companies and the benefits were average at best.

We were very agile where Optum acquired us but were assimilated.  Resistance was futile.

pros: Every department and team are run differently than each other. I was directed by a bad leader but when I told others who worked in different areas what I went through, they were surprised because their team was not like that, they had more flexibility. Their teams could work from home more than 1-2 days a week. Some teams were off at noon on Friday's during the summer. UHG did have some fun after work events and when we had long office meetings, food was provided. We were taken to lunch on occasion. We attended a Twins game in a suite. They had an annual two day off-site cabin forum.
cons: Hiring process was a little much- takes about 1-2 months. I had phone interviews with a CA recruiter, a digital interview, calls with a MN recruiter, then finally two in-person interviews. The acceptance package was never explained, just given a lot of paperwork, links, etc to figure it out. They never had a formal orientation. I spent my first day pulled into conference calls and meetings, instead of getting building tours, familiar with my team and surroundings. There is no on-site IT support, you call someone if you need help. I had to set-up my computer, phone, email, etc. I was never taught how to use the HR website for benefits, goals, etc. I figured it out on my own. Parking isn't the best. They needed more on-site parking. You need to be there by 8am to get parking in their ramp otherwise you are in ramp across the road and walk or take shuttle. Benefits, especially health insurance options aren't that great for a health insurance company. Don't offer basic insurance PPO options, just high cost HSA's. They had a 4 hr PTO policy even for salary EE's so if you had 45+ hours in by Friday at noon and wanted to leave you still had to take 4 hrs PTO. The biggest flaw UHG had with my experience was what I went through. I was sought out by a recruiter. I was in a good job with a good company and leader and I had flexibility. Before I went in for a second interview, I told the hiring manager I was working from home two days a week and that I needed to know what their WFH policy was. I told her work-life balance was important to me and that I didn't want to waste her or I's time. Her response was it'd be worth my while to come in so I did. They knew my current flexibility and said they offer this too and that their teams work from home. I got into the job 4-6 months later to find out there was no formal WFH policy. Some teams worked from home 1-2 days and others more. There was no consistency. When my kid's summer schedule hit, I revisited my two days WFH to be told it should only be one. Then when I wanted a consistent one day a week from home just during the summer, I was told it would need to be determined weekly. The job posting indicated no travel and it was not disclosed to me during the interview or hiring process but our team did travel to clients when needed. My team worked through lunches and even while on PTO. There were constant meetings, mostly internal or development meetings but it did take away from my actual day-to-day work. I spent most of my weeks in meetings or on conferences calls. I had 1-1 meetings with four different leaders and it was confusing because my direct boss would be good with something but someone higher would say otherwise so I never knew whose direction to take, again a lot of inconsistency and poorly managed teams. When I resigned I wasn't told they didn't have to pay out my PTO balance and they didn't. They were also supposed to take my HSA balance out of my final check but didn't. They told me it was mine to use but two months later I got a bill from UHG. They never sent me an exit interview or survey. My BEST ADVICE to someone considering employment with UHG is to get employment details such as WFH arrangement and schedules, travel, hours or busy seasons outlined in the offer letter because they will not disclose this information and will trick you into taking the job because they feel they have more to offer to you than what is truly most important to you.

review_title: Not the Best, Not the Worst
pros:
+ Competitive salary and benefits
I felt that salary offers on initial hiring  ($55k-$65k range) were competitive with the broader market. PTO benefit of 23 days for <5 years of service (28 afterwards) is fantastic. Company also offers 15% discounted stock purchase plan.

+ Good work life balance 
I hardly ever worked over 40 hours during non-peak times such (However, this is entirely dependent on your team/function -- your experience will vary.) 50 hour weeks are normal during close periods for finance functions as well as the occasional working Saturday/holiday during quarter closes.  Never had issues taking PTO here and there but extended PTO (around 5+ days) during busy times is at the discretion of your manager. Working from home on occasion (whether with purpose or just to save a day of commuting) was never a problem for me but this will very much be team dependent.

+Challenging work and plenty of opportunity
This organization is so enormous with so many moving parts that there is always a new problem to solve and a better way to do things. Additionally, the internal job board always has an abundance of postings. There is an incredible amount of internal movement within the organization which can help keep things fresh if you feel you've grown bored with your current day-to-day and are ready to accomplish something new without leaving UHG entirely.
cons:
-- Budget targets are king
Raises during good years for top performers staying within the same salary grade will be in the 2% range, and the bonus pool is typically funded between 50% - 70% of the maximum payout (again, during good times). If you want your pay to beat inflation you will generally need to be aggressive and shop yourself around the org or look elsewhere. If your team goes to happy hour or has a working lunch session you will be paying for it yourself unless your manager is feeling generous that day.

-- Lack of attachment to broader organization
Due to the sheer size of the organization and a derth of little things (pizza parties, happy hours, mixers, company swag etc.) I did not develop an attachment to the organization as a whole. I did feel very much just like an employee id number.  If you are looking for an organization where you will have company outings, events, or unique perks that will give you the warm fuzzies, look elsewhere. There is no real culture in this company for FP&A -- mostly just heads down, get-in get-out, with the occasional water cooler conversation. Some will care about this more than others depending on your personality type.

If you can live with the above, UHG is a fine place to work. If not, you will be miserable here -- look elsewhere.

We attract very smart, experienced, highly educated people who are committed to their work: physicians, epidemiologists, actuaries, health services researchers, software architects and engineers, programmers and dba's. In a company such as Ingenix that requires investment in technology, research and development as well as innovation, there is insufficient willingness to make reasonable investment today for pay-off tomorrow.  This results in fits and starts of activity as previously approved budgets and projects are canceled or delayed.  There is also a lack of respect from senior management to other employees.

job_title: Database Analyst (Independent Contractor) in West Valley, UT
pros: Co-workers were pleasant enough, office had a nice view.
cons:
BACKGROUND:  As an expert database manager and analyst with a dozen years experience serving some of the top corporations in the nation - I was brought in by Ingenix to help validate their database of client companies - easily numbering in the many tens of thousands. My end of the 6-12 month project would require verifying Parent Company associations - by any means of internet research possible. 

To help you understand the importance and complexity of my end of the project - Ingenix had contracted to pay roughly $12,000 per month for my professional services.

There was no set method of research. Ingenix described the job as "highly ambiguous". It was essentially looking for needles in haystacks - but, Ingenix couldn't even tell where the haystacks were. They are in the middle of database migration - and their database has been contaminated by errant  and outdated information.

REQUIREMENTS:  Learn three fairly complex software programs from scratch, learn how to apply these programs to Ingenix's project needs. Again, there was no "official" way to conduct the research - it was locating random company associations from random internet sources ranging from corporate websites to business directories to business news blurbs.

TRAINING: No project trainer onsite. Training was conducting via telephone and desktop sharing from 2,000 miles away - I kid you not!

RESULT: A mere TEN DAYS into the assignment (while my colleague and I were still receiving training) - I get a phone call from the Project Manager (again, from 2,000 miles away) - ending my services on the grounds that I wasn't "getting it quick enough". NO advanced warning, nor indication that anything was amiss in their minds. NOTHING. 

"Not getting it"? I'd done database analysis for Boeing 747 jet aircraft! This was a sick joke. Ingenix brings in a professional to do a professional's job - and then treats him with the disregard too often afforded an entry-level file clerk. I have been a project manager, so it is not with some level of expertise that I assert - this project manager was operating outside of her element.

Higher management is most likely the most incompetent I have ever worked for. This is a multi billion dollar health management company which gives very little reward for doing well other than "be grateful you have a job." There are far too many layers of management. The parent company continues to buy the competition and smaller companies but the infrastructure can't handle it all and regularly collapses. Departments have been created where staff literally have nothing to do, while other departments are overwhelmed with too many customers and not enough staff. 

Although employees are told customer service is number one priority it is clearly not, based upon daily feedback from customers calling to complain. There is an unwritten but obvious push to make the most profit for stockholders as much as possible regardless of cost. Staff are punished with low metric scores if you spend too much time helping an individual customer. (For example you lose points if you spend more than 5 minutes total with a customer including note time). Calls are routinely misdirected and protocol dictates you transfer again even though you have the skill and information to help them. Upper management does not involve direct staff in changing operational procedures based upon hands on knowledge.

The few bonuses which exist are based 100% on metrics and not soft skills. Employees are encouraged to ask the customer if they would give them a good review. Insurance is cheap, but you have to fight to get dental claims paid.

The environment is extremely unhealthy for a healthcare company.  The restroom is so far away some days I don't go at all. The desks are not ergonomically correct and can create back, shoulder, and elbow pain not previously experienced. review_title: Experience is very dependent on the team to which you are assigned
pros:
*The work can be incredibly interesting
*The diversity of projects affords the opportunity to learn a lot
*If you are on the right team, you will have a very positive experience--some of the managers are great and really push for your growth
*If you work under the right senior VP you can really shine and grow
*Some managers are very understanding about flexible work schedules (including options to work odd hours or work from home)
cons:
*Problems with organic growth. Only one or two current VPs (out of more than 10) were promoted from within. There is an unspoken understanding that you can only grow to a certain level at Lewin, and that after that you have to leave if you want to grow. The result of this is that we hire VPs who are far less capable of doing the job then some of our internal senior staff.
*There is a bit of a car-rental lot mentality at Lewin, where many of the senior management staff seem to think that you don't bring anything special to the table, and that you can be used interchangeably with other staff
*Your experience at Lewin is very dictated by the "team" (market) to which you are assigned--some of the team leaders (executive management) are truly wonderful to work for and with, but unfortunately others are not. We have one team in particular with extremely high rates of turnover and an executive leader who tends to bully rather than lead.
*There is very little culture at Lewin--the broader United Health (our parent's parent) has really pushed culture over the past year or so (e.g., encouraging accountability, "being here now", compassion and empathy), and when you engage with direct United employees you are REALLY aware of this sense of culture and belonging, but Lewin has been very resistant to this. Most of our management staff has gone through culture and management raining because they were requried to, and unfortunately very few of them actually grew from the trainings or apply what they learned. 
*There is a good deal of bureaucracy here, with a lot of emphasis on degrees and years and not enough emphasis on actual competency.

review_title: Employee-time flexibility, a lot of virtual teams, un-innovative, political, 50th percentile pay for industry
pros: Employee-time flexibility, a lot of virtual teams
cons:
Unninnovative company with questionable, low-risk, finance-focused leadership that is pretty similar to that in its sister company, UnitedHealthcare, which is also under the UnitedHealth Group umbrella. 

Unfortunately, leadership that knows how to run a health insurance business is incredibly inadequate to run an information technology, services and consulting business. 

UnitedHealth Group is looking to prepare Optum for a spin-off and doing the whole "lipstick on a pig" routine by artificially inflating the financial results for it. Since only UnitedHealth Group (UNH) has to follow GAAP accounting rules, money transfers can be made internally to make Optum look good (at UnitedHealthcare's expense). Wall Street does not seem to have caught on to this completely-legal trick that Optum has been successfully using for the past 2 years to make the financial results look fantastic. All the top executives at UnitedHealth Group are looking to make a killing on the expected stock-price increase (at least in the short run) when Optum is spun off. But the party will not last long. 

Also, employee morale is really low because of lay-offs that have been happening (under the radar) over the past 2 years -- all part of the cost-cutting measures to inflate earnings.

The culture is extremely bad and highly political. The new, highly publicized "Culture" initiative has been a failure because management actions do not match their words. Also, Human Resources is mostly outsourced to Mercer -- so there is no HR presence helping in employee and company culture initiatives.

review_title: This job might not be for you
job_title: Pharmacy Technician Prior Authorization in San Diego, CA
pros:
When hired you'll spend 3 weeks in a classroom setting 8-5 M-F learning about their computer systems and how they work. My instructor was great and he helped us (20 trainees) learn as much as we could in the time we had together.
The pay that they start you off at is good, too.
cons:
I felt like I was misled in the entire process as to what we were going to be doing at this job. Pharmacy Technician Prior Authorization is a 100% call center job. You will work in a cubicle all day and answer phone calls from disgruntled customers and doctors/nurses. It can be very frustrating.

While I could have easily continued to do this type of work, the scheduling was what got me.
They tell you that you won't have to do any overtime or work weekends for the first 30 days. 

Then after one day, all that changes. They have mandatory overtime, 14 hours a week, broken down into 2 hours each M-F shift and 4 hours on Saturdays. You cannot get out of this. You can negotiate how the +14 hours will be divided up, but that's it. So if you have family or things going on outside of work, forget it. 

While they pretend that the mandatory overtime is just week to week, it's rather indefinitely, which helps them skirt the laws regarding mandatory overtime in the state of California. 

So to sum it up, don't believe everything they tell you. It's a huge company with lots of turnover. You're working in a George Orwell novel, where employees just quit and disappear on a regular basis, nobody knows where they went. You computer will dictate when you have your breaks and lunch, etc. Cameras everywhere. They're monitoring and grading all your interactions on the phone with every call you take, everything you type into your computer.

If you have no life and can or want to work 54 hour+ weeks and make a ton of overtime money, then take this job. It just comes down to what you value.

So having said all that- if you are one who likes to be in a combative mold  everyday, worried about if you can or cannot take off, call in due to an emergency, or take off due to sickness, then by all means you might want to work in this call center and enjoy each and every work day. review_title: Strengthening the control environment could enhance operations
pros: Compensation is tremendous including base salary and bonus structure.  Most staff are friendly and intelligent.  Frequent social and charitable activities help morale.  Good work/life balance.
cons:
On-boarding was poor and lacked relevance.  Materials should have included a road map for success with defined roles and responsibilities of position.
Management is poor and ineffective.  I feel that my manager set me up for failure and did not follow through on her promises including getting my input on projects I wanted to work on and approving training I wanted.  She claimed after I started that she would be an advocate for me when in fact she was anything but.  I constantly had to go to her for work, and remind her of training requests I needed approval on.  Furthermore, she scheduled me for projects that she wasn't even sure of.  Feedback was mostly critical/negative rather than constructive and often merely based on hearsay and anecdotal which from a manager is taken as gospel.  While there are resources on HR Direct like LearnSource where you can chart your development, management is extremely critical of everything you do so unless they approve of you, you will not succeed in the department.  This can be challenging since managers often communicated poorly if at all to m.  For instance, roles and responsibilities of various staff members are not clear or updated anywhere for staff to see and managers did not communicate these expectations to me until it was too late.  Some managers have different expectations so that complicates matters further.  Without this communication and coaching from management I often felt sabotaged instead of empowered.  What I learned in time was that managers delegate most of the roles and responsibilities they are listed as responsible for on that document online downward and Leads do it as well often without telling their team.  Turnover is quite high and one director seemed proud of that as she boasted that many staff don’t last six months while complaining how hard it is to fire people.  Managers excel at negative feedback and seemingly would rather get rid of staff than develop them or they lack the skills to develop them.  I had to constantly bring up examples of my contributions since managers will either minimize or ignore any and were all too ready to detail my weaknesses/faults which were not tied to any data/metrics and had little impact on the project.  Worse yet, managers are arrogant and overconfident in their leadership abilities and seem to be above reproach as they are consistently rewarded and praised by senior leadership.  Most of the department training is trivial and lacks practicality.  Since feedback is such a big part of the department and staff are so poor at giving it that should be a focus of training.  A big part of feedback is supporting it with documentation of examples rather than hearsay/subjective statements.  The feedback would be a lot more credible and constructive if it outlined strengths as well as weaknesses (balanced).  Concise, constructive, balanced and timely feedback was the exception rather than the rule as management lack the skills to consistently provide this.  Therefore, feedback was employed as a tool to knock an employee down by cherry picking those incidents that fit a narrative.  My manager revisited past performance reviews to solicit negative feedback on me despite it being my first project.  She even questioned the experience on my resume which was interesting since during my actual job interview she had no questions.  She then told me that she knew I requested more balanced feedback from her boss which made it more probable that retaliation was a motive.  She and the VP who was with her at the time should have given me kudos for bringing this to senior management’s attention since unlike them my feedback was valid, constructive and factual.  I used to audit offices with similar cultures so I can identify the symptoms of such a toxic work environment.  During my time in the department my intent was to help them meet their objectives and identify and mitigate risks that could have a negative impact.  In my experience management posed the biggest such risk to the department’s success as they only seemed to care about their own interests.

review_title: Great place to start a consulting career
pros:
The Lewin Group is one of the smaller consulting firms in the DC area but offers access the same clients and projects that larger firms acquire.  The small nature of the company offers junior staff many opportunities to lead tasks, work directly with the client and become trained to be a subject matter expert. 
Lewin hires some of the smartest, hardest working people and everyone that works there is invested in their job and willing to go the extra mile to deliver a superior product. 
The management is genuinely interested in employee satisfaction. Management takes employee survey results very seriously and utilizes feedback to develop new programs and/or help staff find projects they are interested in.  Lewin also values work/life balance and aims to give employees the time off they need and allow for a flexible schedule. 
Lewin is a quickly becoming a well known consulting firm for health care reform and is winning very large projects to help with the different components of ACA.
cons:
While Lewin is very invested in employee satisfaction, they do not offer a lot of opportunities or resources for professional development. Employees have to seek out opportunities independently and many times, pay for them out of their own pocket. It is also hard to find time to do professional development because there is such a strong focus on billing targets and utilization. 
There is also an expectation for all staff to be involved in business development (proposal writing) while billing at the normal rate. This can become very difficult during proposal season when resources are not plentiful and staff have to dedicate many hours outside the normal work day to help with proposal development. 
Additionally, Lewin is very heavy with junior staff straight from their graduate programs. Lewin needs to hire more senior staff with relevant subject matter expertise to help guide client work.

This is more of a reflection on my last 2-3 years of experience with Optum/UHG. The SJC office is no longer there. All Optum HIE positions have now been moved to Raleigh. The office once belonged to Axolotl which was acquired by UnitedHealth Group around 2011.

- The people I had worked with there were generally very friendly and helpful, I've made a lot of lasting friendships
- Good work/life balance for the most part except for a short time when a certain leadership team was in place
- 25 vacation days
- The software we built had a meaningful impact
- Nice office location in downtown San Jose
- We got individual cubes, which is getting rarer nowadays in tech. I like the privacy.
cons:
The major con was that UnitedHealth kind of hid its intention to close the San Jose site for a while. The office was closed down in mid-2016 without a very long warning period. We had a lot of talented people get let go. The jobs were moved to Raleigh, NC, probably to save on costs. There are great people in Raleigh too, but I just think doing this to employees who gave a lot of their careers to the company is disappointing.

But here were the cons when the company was there

- Not too many perks, for example, free food is very rare. That's different from a lot of SV companies
- Pay was a notch below average, maybe by %15
- Poor health insurance, mostly high deductible plans. It's actually not surprising that a health insurance company knows how to cut costs on health insurance
- Internet access was restricted. The firewall apparently blocks any website it doesn't know about so helpful resources are often inaccessible
- We were slow to adopt new technologies

- Very understaffed in underwriting. Management focuses on initiatives to write more business, but doesn't adjust staffing appropriately to coincide with increased work volume.

pros: So Dignity Health outsourced their rev cycle  to a giant for-profit company which slashed pay and benefits, causing the best folks to quit and the remaining unhappy. job_title: Provider Resolution Specialist in Richardson, TX
pros: Option to work from home, monthly bonuses, and we are treated with respect from upper management. Everything is graded for performance by a completely separate team other than your supervisors so the harder you work to meet your monthly goals the better your numbers and percentages are and they definitely do reward their hard working employees. We had a 14 week training class and it was absolutely fantastic, our trainer really enjoys her job and worked very hard to get the class ready to be on our own. There are a few things you can't teach and we just had to learn what to do when that time came, but I felt so prepared once I got on the floor-- I really do love my job! I also enjoy having weekends off and the office closes at 7pm every evening during the week. United healthcare has such a positive atmosphere and it really helps getting through those not so easy days in the call center. Another thing I absolutely love is VTO--voluntary time off. I've never worked for a company that offered this and it is extremely helpful if you're feeling sick and want to go home but don't want to get penalized for missing work.
cons: It's challenging and takes a little bit of time getting used to being on a set schedule, we have a separate department that tells us when to take breaks and lunches. You just have to get everything prepared before you log on for the day to take calls, as extra bathroom breaks and any time away from the desk that isn't built into your schedule can hurt your goal percentage for the day.

pros: Flexible schedule, can work an 8hr shift between (6am-8pm), work at home available, about 4weeks of PTO (getting time off is an easy process), lots of OT, work environment was easy going and laid back.

review_title: Fine job for short term, not a place to work for life.
pros: It is a fortune 25 company that looks great on a resume. The company is telecommuter friendly. There are opportunities to advance-but they are usually in other departments.  The salary is decent, but they usually do not tell you that you will be working 60 hours a week for that salary. There is a decent amout of time off per year. The company does have annual employee surveys and management is required to come up with a plan on how they will correct things the employees have issues with indicating that they are making an effort.  I do have some great co-workers that work very hard and are great to work with.
cons: You would think a health insurance company would have good health benefits, but that is simply not the case (for example I had to file a formal appeal for a second round of antibiotics when sick with bronchitis-the company said they were not covered). Communication between departments is horrible, and you often learn about things by reading the newspaper. The company is so concerned about shareholder and bottom line they forget the importance of employees being happy. A perfect review (literally perfect) got me less than 1% of my annual salary as a bonus, and no raise. This will be the second year in a row they are refusing to give raises for some departments, leaving me at the same salary for 2 years now. I am not alone in this. Once you are in, you will never get a decent raise again (a direct quote from HR to me).

job_title: Health Advisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: At the Green Bay site, supervisors are supportive. The site's facilities are very nice. There are (usually) people to assist with difficult questions that you may not have the answer to. Co-workers are generally friendly, although I suppose that depends on the batch you get put into. If you wanted to move up the food chain, opportunities are available if you're willing to stick out 6-9 months on the phones AFTER training.
cons: Mandatory overtime of up to 2 hours a day. No sick days. Extremely difficult to schedule Personal Time Off (PTO). Extremely difficult to meet all metrics--you are expected to have an average call time of 6 minutes, while still doing everything necessary to go "above and beyond". Necessary to keep 10+ computer applications running all day. The Health Advisor role consists of taking call after call after call with little to no down time between calls (the average between-call time is between 7-14 seconds). During training, you are packed into a tiny room with 15+ other people, trying to talk on the phone with members. After training, you are shipped out to the floor, which is a sea of 5x5 cubicles. When you put in your two weeks' notice, opportunities suddenly become available to lure you into staying, but none of them are guaranteed ("smoke and mirrors" as I put it). Depends on the person, but $12.50 hourly isn't enough to make a living if you have expenses like rent, gas, etc.

review_title: For a company making record profits their pay is far from competitive.

If member asked for supervisor, we were told to tell them that either one wasn't available or that they would give the member the same answer and wouldn't really be able to help them anyway.

job_title: Claims Associate in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Air conditioning, good benefits, don't have to deal with anyone on the phone.
cons:
Mandatory OT as inventory is booming due to the Baby Boomer generation all becoming eligible at once. It takes a year of "ramp up" training to make you an effective processor, so you can be stuck working 10-14 hours of MANDATORY overtime PER WEEK for months or years on end. They ask you when you apply "would you be wiling to work OT" and you say yes because you want the job, then they own you. For less stress, and several dollars more (like 15/hr) you can do the same work they'll be training you to do with medial coding and whatnot, for a local hospital. 

Also, no one will tell you this, but they do not want to promote from within, esp from Claims. They desperately need their experienced processors, but instead of rewarding them to keep them, they rely on the state of our economy to keep you there. I am more qualified for positions within the company such as Proposal Writer, due to my experience in management and degree in English Lit, but because I accepted a claims position initially... they will tell you it is unreasonable to believe that you could jump more than one pay grade. They'll give you the "well, we can only offer up to a 10% increase based on your CURRENT pay within the company..." but you're applying for a different job, that the company gives a grade level 27 and they might offer someone off the street 75k, but only offer you a 10-20% increase of your current claims salary and pressure you to say that's the company policy. So, find the Pay Grade map by state and city on the company's site, see what THEY believe these positions are worth by grade, and then let them know that you wont settle for less. Period. If they want you, they'll take you, or you walk.

cons: Older technology and a commitment to that technology, no real training, not enough people to do the work because they laid off so many people along the way to meet quarterly earnings projections  (which is the main problem and the reason for the rest of the cons), no true development environment, project management is sort of a new thing here - no standards,  and they only want yes men in management. job_title: Compliance Resolution Specialist in Harlingen, TX
pros: If you work hard and you're dedicated you'll go far. The pay is good 16+ dollars an hour. The leadership is open to new ideas from their employees and upper management is not out of reach of your average employee - I work in Harlingen Texas and seeing upper management from the corporate side talking with average employees to gauge what the mood of your average employee is not an abnormal thing to see(Of course, you're never going to see the old man, Mr. Hemsley running around the floor, but with what he does, is that really a shocker? He's running a multi billion dollar company). They're constantly using our feedback to try to make our jobs easier. There's a brass ring here at this job and it's up to you to grab it. If you're fortunate enough to get a supervisor by the name of Debbie Y. then you're in a unique position to go far if you give her your all. I'm an example of that - within a year I had worked as front line customer service, ORS research, CRS(compliance) loaner to full time loaner - not because I was perfect at my job, far from it - but I showed up on time every day, gave it my all and owned up to my mistakes and learned. I can't praise this company enough for the first time in my life I feel like I have a job where the sky is the limit.
cons:
30 minute lunches.

Benefits(health insurance)

Micromanagment every minute spent on the floor(but with some of the crap I've seen employees pull, I can't really blame them)

The first few months at the job are going to be pure hell, simply put. But if you can overcome those first few months you'll quickly finding yourself getting in the flow of the job and it'll become second hand nature.

job_title: Healthcare Decision Support Coach in Richardson, TX

Back to the benefits, my medical benefits were outstanding.  I had a relapse of an intermittent-but-chronic problem right when I started my job. OptumHealth/UnitedHealthcare & Ms Eckman stood with me.  They let me start a month later, & even then, I was in-&-out of the ER/inpatient unit(s) with exacerbations for the first 5 months of my job.  OptumHealth (360) "bent over backwards" to get me some kind of version of unofficial short-term leave(s).  Even though I didn't get paid some of that time, I STILL had a job when I got out of hospital!  Amazing company & supervisors!
cons: I felt it very difficult to complete ALL of the parameters of the patient call that were desired within the short time frame.  I tried all that my generous supervisor (& other management, employees, & even friends) suggested to speed things up to NO AVAIL.  Also, there was a little bit of ambivalence by the upper management regarding the triage outcomes for a short time; this made my calls take a bit longer.  (That ambivalence may have just been perceived by a few of us staff nurses.)  I was eventually "let go" over this "slowness" of mine.  But the severance was amicable.  I even left there with no supervisor/management evaluations less than 85% on my calls; & all my patient evaluations of my calls were 95% or higher!

review_title: Hands down, the best organziation I've ever worked for. I've been through corporate america for over 20 years.
job_title: Revenue Cycle Back End Ops in Melville, NY
pros: I cannot say enough of the management teams here. They assembled teams, but most important is our work ethic. Good strong, roll up your sleeves and get right into it attitude. Decent pay, good work hours, awesome benefits, great dedicated people.
cons: I don't know if this is a "Con" per say, but...If you're like me, you just get down to business and keep going. You will immerse yourself in what we do and most importantly, you will assist our patients.  Which will take time from you being home. There are those that simply do their 9 to 5, but as for myself? I want to just keep going.  It can be stressful to some, who are not focused on the goal....The goal is to make out patients feel as if we are the answer to what issues they may have financially.  Educate our patients as they go through a stressful enough process regarding why they're there in the first place, on healthcare insurances and their respective coverage's. Everyone is different, and I strive to treat and assist each one according to their unique needs and questions. I sometimes don't know when to go home.  Well, they systems do require daily maintenance, and I am forced to log off and go home, so there is a time limit set. Even when I want to keep going.  If you're like me, already paid your dues in corporate america and want to help others, this company is for you. My wife understands my drive, so she is ok with it, but if you simply take the job for a paycheck, then this isnt for you. You MUST care about heaping others. If its all about you, and what you can get out of it, you will be found out, and thats where you will get stuck.
